headline: Oatmeal Raisin Cookies
description: These oatmeal raisin cookies bake up soft and chewy with crispy edges. The whole family will love the flavor and texture of this old standby recipe.

video.name: How to Make Oatmeal Raisin Cookies

name: Oatmeal Raisin Cookies

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Line two cookie sheets with parchment paper or silicone liners.
Beat butter, white sugar, and brown sugar in a large bowl until smooth and creamy. Beat in eggs and vanilla until fluffy.
Stir together flour, baking soda, cinnamon, and salt. Gradually beat into the butter mixture. Stir in oats and raisins. Drop teaspoonfuls of batter onto the prepared cookie sheets.

Bake in the preheated oven until golden brown, 8 to 10 minutes, switching racks halfway through. Remove from the oven and let sit on the cookie sheets for 1 to 2 minutes before transferring cookies to a wire rack to cool completely.

review.reviewBody: These came out better than I imagined. I added an additional 1/4 cup of flour, 1/2 tsp of almond extract and 1/4 cup of raisins. This was recommended by a previous post. I will definitely make these again.
I followed the steps mixing wet and dry ingredients separately. Then I slowly added dry to wet. The cookies were flat and thin. I turned the heat down from 375 to 350 but it didn’t help.

Just out of the oven and i am fending myself away from the cooling tray. I got about 50 biscuits so probably my teaspoon was a bit small, though it was more than a teaspoon regular i’m sure. Added walnut, 1/4 cup, used 1 cu coconut sugar, used wholewheat flour and added cardomom. They seem great to me, a bit more crumbly at this stage than chewy, but not over sweet. I find baked goods oversweet in general.
Easy and the result looked very much like the pictures in the recipe.
I'm mixed on these cookies... they tasted great, but the texture was very gooey. They had a hard time setting up.

If only I had read the reviews first, UGH! My cookies were so flat they were almost see-through. They tasted okay, but not fantastic. I'm wondering if butter-flavor Crisco would help them not to spread. They definitely need more flour.
like them

Pretty good, not my fave. Added the 1/4c flour and 1/2 tsp baking soda per other reviews. Slightly less sugar. Made with dried cranberries and pecans. Looking for crunchy edges and chewy centers. Cooked 9 mins.
Very delicious cookies!! I added extra raisins and they turned out perfectly!
Ugh way way too thin. Should have read the reviews and added additional flour and baking soda. Maybe even chilled the dough before cooking as well. Super thin and disappointing ☹️
World's best oatmeal raisin cookies! Making them a second time for sure!

I liked these cookies much better than my mom's old Betty Crocker recipe. I used dark brown sugar which added a little molasses to the taste. I'll tweak the recipe to adjust sweetness and texture to my taste, but overall it is a winner as it is.
Easy to follow and delicious!
My church family , my wife and I all loved these cookies and we can never eat enough of them.
These cookies ran so thin after baking and would not cook in the middle no matter what! I might try again with the suggested additional flour and baking powder.
Browned the butter and reverse creamed this recipe then refrigerated overnight. Delicious.
made it as is, pretty bland if you ask me. perhaps I should have read the other reviews. I'll try again.

Made exactly as written. I was surprised that they didn't flatten at all. They came out pretty much as scooped out, but they had a bit of a crunch on the outside and were chewy in the middle and tasted great. I used my #40 scoop. 3/4 oz. I wouldn't change anything.
Very good cookies. Great tastimg.

One person suggested using a cup of butter and I did that. Following the recipe exactly as written other than that. They went as thin as a penny, white in the middle and very brown around the edges. Not at all what I was hoping for. That happens - no big deal.

These were delicious, soft and chewy. I noticed people saying they used TBS and not tsp for them, that will definitely change cook time and so on. My mom would say “read the recipe twice through before proceeding!” Always good advice.

Even though I don't have a mixer I used a whisk and spatula, they turned out super awesome I baked them for 12 minutes I used a 1 1/2 tbls cookie scoop. Also refrigerate the dough for 25 minutes no longer.
No. I went right by the recipe. The cookies were soft,tender and moist. Recipe is a keeper. Thank you Allrecipes.
They taste great, but the are as flat as can be! I stopped after the first batch, and decided the refrigerate the dough before baking any more.
Followed the recipe to a tee, except I didn’t have enough to raisins so I used chocolate chips for half the batch. They turned out perfect!
I followed the recipe, even the crazy transition and wait times, and cooked them in the oven for a total of 8 minutes, and turned out chewy in the middle once done.

These cookies are delicious! I made them a tablespoon in size as first recommended, but they needed more time than 10 minutes. They were also very small. I made the next batch heaping teaspoonfuls and increased the cook time to around 12 minutes. I also added a half cup of cranberries because I like a little more fruit than what was recommended. They are indeed crunchy on the outside and soft inside. Yum!
My cookies came out wonderful I added 1 tablespoon of molasses to the mixture. The neighbors kid came back for seconds.

I added another 1/2 cup of oats and 1 cup chocolate chips. I also used self rising flour instead of all purpose and baking soda. Turned out great. They did run just a little but I may have put to much mix in one spot.
I followed the adjustments some other reviews Left and I they turned out amazing. One of my pans was stainless steel so that's why some are flatter...I did add additional time with those .
Super yummy 🤤 Kids and adults love these ❤️ Delicious 😋
Good, but better the next day, not too sweet
Made this recipe a few times as it is and loved every time.

While the recipe itself I feel is great, The 375ﾟ did not work for me. All my cookies spread out flat and that was cold out of the refrigerator. The last batch I lowered the temperature to 350 and they've turned out perfect. Pictured is how flat they spread out at 375 I feel like it melted the butter too fast. They still taste good though:)
The only change I made to the recipe was increasing the butter to 1 cup. The cookies were crispy and chewy just like they should be.
Was easy to use and they came out really good

The edges are crisp, the inside is chewy. There’s a good amount of cinnamon and not too few or too little raisins. The only reason I gave this four stars is my personal taste is for thicker, fluffier cookies. I would give it 4.5 stars if I could.

Cookies came out looking like peanut brittle made with raisins instead of peanuts. I’ve always favored Allrecipes, but this one is a big disappointment. Maybe 1/2 cup of butter as opposed to 3/4 cup is best.
So good! We stocked to the recipe and these came out perfect and chewy.
The cookies are great! I took Becky Black’s advise and added ½ cup flour & tsp baking powder. I also threw in a shake of cloves and nutmeg. Will be making them again.
I made the recipe, which was good. I used golden raisins rather than traditional black raisins. I would add a bit more cinnamon next time, since I wasn't able to detect the cinnamon in the cookies.
Change the raisins to Craisins dried cranberries
loved them. Made 3 dozen large cookies. 12 minutes was just right for the size I made.

Awesome recipe. I made it for my cousin for his birthday :) and he loved them. put them in for 9 minutes and they came out wonderfully. Perfect balance between crispy and chewy (in my opinion). I highly recommend this recipe.
This was a great recipe! Definitely soft and chewy, but crispy on the outside! Loved the cookies. I added nuts too!

My first attempt at this left the roof of my mouth feeling like it had been sandpapered. The flavor was good but the texture was dry. What I did the second time around was soak the oatmeal and raisins in a cup of milk and let it stand for 30 minutes Then I just dumped all of the ingredients in and went at it with the hand blender. Voila! Nice soft cookies.
This recipe was perfect for me. Simple and tasty and quick. Thank you.
Didn't change a thing in first batch. Second one I used chocolate chips & Skor bites. Both were yummy !
I only had ¾ cup of raisins so I added a ½ cup of chocolate chips. The results were great!
They are the perfect cookie! My husband loves them, they are our new favourite!
I made it as the recipe says except I added a 1/4 cup more raisins and my family loved the cookies. My husband is not a baker but has been a chef and he gave it a thumbs up.
we made these in 4 different batches. 1-with dried cranberries 2- with dried cherries 3. plain oatmeal 4-with peanut butter

Wow. Did I say wow? I meant it. For dietary reasons (like cookies are part of a diet!) I used all whole wheat flour and thick cut oats, but other than adding more cinnamon, made these as directed. I honestly don't know how many I made because there was a cookie monster in my house eating them as quickly as I could make them. I didn't have a full cup of raisins so I added some cranberries and almonds and they are great. I made them for an event here this weekend, but don't think they will make it that long. Great recipe!!

I followed the recipe exactly and got great results. I wouldn't normally buy (or make) oatmeal raisin cookies but I had the ingredients and Googled a recipe. They are delicious with just the right mix of crispiness and moistness. I baked for nine minutes at first and switched to 10 for later batches.

Yikes. I consider myself to be a decent cookie baker. But this recipe made me feel like I missed 10 ingredients. Followed the recipe to a tee, baked at 375 for 8min, they looked burnt but still gooey in the middle. Did one pan for 9min and the pic is the result. Not sure what happened or what to fix. But I probably wont ever use this recipe again. Wasted someone elses ingredients. Super disappointed.
I didn’t change a thing and they were magnificent!
Nope My Family Loves Them Me 2 Tsvm 4 Sharing This Recipe
These cookies turned out wonderful! My family loves these cookies!
Definitely will be making these again :) they turned out so good!

This was a really delicious oatmeal cookie recipe. I would make this again since it was soft in the middle and crunchy on the sides. And the flavor is just so tasty. The only adjustment I made when making the cookies was I thought the temperature was a little too hot. I baked the cookies at 350 F. for about the time shown in the recipe and they were fine. Additionally, I added some chopped walnuts to the batter. Thanks for a really good recipe.
These cookies were delicious and chewy! Crowd pleasers for sure!
Delicious. I added the extra 1/4 flour and 1/4 tsp baking soda. My husband raved about it!
Recipe was fine just added a little more vanilla ...great taste.
Delicious. I made the recipe exactly as it appears and added a cup of chopped walnuts. They were perfect
Great recipe for the simplicity alone. So close to my Grandmother's recipe even fooled a couple of her children.

I made these cookies twice; the first time was Thanksgiving & the 2nd time today. I had all the ingredients & they were a big hit with the Thanksgiving crowd! They were crispy on the bottom & chewy on top. I also added 1/2 c. Craisins & 1/2 c. Choc chips. Instead of raisins. This time I was short 3/4 c. Oats & substituted @ tsp syrup, because I had no vanilla. The batter was thinner than the 1st time & I worried they wouldn't be as good, but voila, they were every bit as good! I even made one batch in a muffin tin & they were slightly "cakey" but still delicious! I am delighted with this recipe, as you can't really go wrong,if you use a little imagination.

Good basic cookie recipe. Cookies could be runny if you are strickt to the recipe which would make thin cokies. Many people say add more flour, I added more rolled oats. I also leave out the you raisins because nobody wants those in cookies. The recipe says it makes 4 dozen, i yeilded about 2 1/2 dozen 2 inch cookies. Very happy with results.
I followed this recipe. The cookies tasted great! I did add some nutmeg. These are warm chewy cookies!
Yummy
It was great!
It was pretty good, maybe a little too many oats for me but delicious none the less.

IT'S SCIENCE; NOT THE RECIPE. This is a standard tried and true cookie recipe. There is no need to changes anything other than your own taste preferences. The ISSUE OF STICKING, HARD COOKIES, FLAT COOKIES and more doesn't have anything to do with the recipe; it has to do with HOW you bake them. If you bake a cookie on a non-stick baking mat, paper, insulated cookie sheet or standard cookie sheet, the cookie will come out different for each. For this bake, I used both the baking mat and the insulated cookie sheet. There was a little more browning on with the mat, and a little cookie residue left on the insulated pan (did not stick). I always decrease sugar for my cookies, but didn't do anything else. They turned out fine. If you do have one of those very old cookie sheets that you've been using for a life time, you might want to try baking your cookies using the mat or paper and I think you will be happier with your results, and have less clean up! I didn't give it a 5 because the recipe would have to be over the top and this is a standard good recipe.
they were great
NOTE: If you “drop by teaspoon fulls” and cook them for 8 minutes, they will be way over done. Flavor wise, they were a bit bland.

I made these (such great ratings!) with no modifications and felt like they were trying to masquerade as chocolate chip cookies (obviously minus the chocolate). Too much flour, not enough oats. I wanted something oatey and gooey and this was not it.

This is my second time making these within 2 weeks. I was so impressed the first time and happy with the results, didn't change a thing. My only problem was being unable to find the raisins I'd purchased the previous day but luckily my neighbor was well stocked. I was happy to thank him with some of these cookies.
Followed intructions to a Tee...They look like flap jacks when pulled out of oven Good flavor thats it...

I followed the instructions in the comments, with extra flour, baking powder, plumped the raisins, but to no avail. My cookies had no sort of cookie form and I had to chip them out of the pan. Very frustrating!!

I have been baking for 50 years, and yes I followed directions exactly. The cookies look nothing like the picture. They ran until paper thin and came out crispy even after shortening cook time on second and third batches. Taste is good like toffee, just not what I was looking for.
Delicious! I ran out of brown sugar about 1/2 cup shy of what recipe calls for, and I added in extra white sugar to make up for it.

Very happy with this recipe. Had no issues. Made half a batch without raisins and the other half with chocolate chips (didn't have raisins). I actually preferred the plain batch! Will definitely try with raisins next time!
Cut down the sugar to 1/2 cup, soak your raisin or cherries in bourbon for an extra kick.
they were realy good but they were too soft so we had to make it 23 min instead of 10 min or 15 min. could have been better.

Second time I've made these. I used craisins instead of raisins since I don't really like raisins.
SO good.
Favorite oatmeal cookie recipe.

I followed this recipe, with the exception of slightly less white sugar. They came out perfectly crisp on the outside and soft throughout. They tasted great! Will be my go-to recipe. I think I’ll add something though for a bit of pop. Not sure what. Thanks for the recipe!
First batch and they are delicious. I added a little extra baking soda and flour and a tsp of molasses..,yummy!!!

Excellent recipe! I substituted butter shortening and added about 1/4 cup of molasses and a teaspoon of nutmeg. Refrigerated the dough and used probably a tablespoon sized drop on an un-greased cookie sheet one insulated and the other non insulated cookie sheets and did not stick to either. Probably went a bit more raisins then called for light and dark , newly opened boxes so the were moist. Cookies are chewy and rich, definitely a keeper! Thanks for posting!
Tried uploading picture but even as smallest size wouldn’t load. It was actually for the nay sayers who claimed they ran and stuck to sheet. Well not here!

Loved this recipe with added walnut pieces
 (1 cup). Perfectly delicious.

Ingredients blend well BUT they need more than a "teaspoon" to produce a decent cookie and you REALLY need to either lower the temp or baking time if you're using nonstick cookie sheets.

Thinking of using parchment paper so we'll see
Chill before rolling into balls. Delicious!
Absolutely wonderful. Soft and delicious-- they didn't stick to the pan or spread. The only thing I changed was I only added 1 egg because I didn't have 2.
I added a little more vanilla and cinnamon as well as chocolate chips. I reduced oats by a cup. Cookies turned out great.
Was super easy

I followed this recipe pretty much exactly as it says and it came out great. I decreased the sugar and soaked the raisins in hot water prior to putting them in the dough but those were the only changes I made. I mixed by hand and made sure to not overwork the dough. Delicious!
These cookies came out delicious.
I made the recipe as is. Fabulous! My wife and I gave some to her son and they loved them too.
A delicious cookie. However, it needs more flour and less sugar. When I baked the cookie, it spread so the cookies touched each other. I gave it an “ok” rating because it was very good.
Outstanding recipe! The best cookies I’ve ever made, and I’m a pretty good baker (following and tweaking existing recipes anyway haha). I added chopped walnuts since I had some on hand.

I just made these cookies. Very Healthy. The recipe says to use a teaspoonful of dough per cookie.
I used a generous Tablespoon and it made 48. Is that a typo in the recipe ? Anyways good cookies.
